subject: Public Speaking
title: Whataboutism and Deflection
description: A fast breakdown of Whataboutism and Deflection for builders.

hook.text: Your country violates human rights. What about yours? Soviet diplomats perfected this technique during the Cold War.

buildup.text: Whataboutism deflects criticism by pointing to the accuser's flaws. It doesn't defend â€” it distracts.

discovery.text: The technique works because it triggers a fairness instinct. People feel the accuser should face their own standard.

twist.text: Logically, it's a fallacy. Someone else's wrongdoing doesn't justify yours. But emotionally, it muddies the water.

climax.text: Whataboutism thrives in debates with time limits. By the time you address the deflection, your point is forgotten.

punchline.text: If you can't defend yourself, attack the accuser.

quiz.question: What is whataboutism?
options: Deflecting criticism by pointing to the accuser's flaws
